CardData.title: Mount Fuji
CardData.paragraph: Mount Fuji, located on Honshu Island, is the highest mountain in Japan at 3,776.24 meters (12,389 feet). It is an active stratovolcano that last erupted in 1707–1708. Mount Fuji is an iconic symbol of Japan and is frequently depicted in art and literature.

CardData.title: Himeji Castle
CardData.paragraph: Himeji Castle is a hilltop Japanese castle complex situated in the city of Himeji. It is one of the finest surviving examples of feudal Japanese castle architecture and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The castle is also known as the White Heron Castle due to its elegant white exterior.

CardData.title: Itsukushima Shrine
CardData.paragraph: Itsukushima Shrine is a Shinto shrine on the island of Itsukushima, also known as Miyajima, in Hiroshima Prefecture. It is famous for its 'floating' torii gate, which appears to be floating in the water at high tide. The shrine and its torii gate are regarded as one of Japan's most scenic views.

CardData.title: Arashiyama Bamboo Grove
CardData.paragraph: The Arashiyama Bamboo Grove is a natural bamboo forest in the Arashiyama district of Kyoto. Walking through the groves, visitors are surrounded by a serene atmosphere and the soothing sounds of bamboo rustling in the wind. It is a popular tourist destination and a symbol of natural beauty in Japan.

CardData.title: Kinkaku-ji
CardData.paragraph: Kinkaku-ji, officially named Rokuon-ji, is a Zen Buddhist temple in Kyoto. It is renowned for its stunning Golden Pavilion, which is covered in gold leaf. The temple is set within a beautiful landscape garden and is designated as a National Special Historic Site and a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

CardData.title: Senso-ji Temple
CardData.paragraph: Senso-ji Temple, also known as Asakusa Kannon Temple, is a Buddhist temple located in Asakusa, Tokyo. It is one of Tokyo's most colorful and popular temples. The temple's main hall and its five-story pagoda are major attractions for visitors.
